Whether this new subvariant, which has now been found in Denmark, South Africa, Israel, the United States, and the United Kingdom, will be anywhere near as disruptive as Omicron remains to be seen. To date there's no indication it triggers more severe illness, the agency said, adding that scientists are studying whether the updated vaccines that will soon be available will protect effectively against BA.2.86. They target the XBB.1.5 version of the virus. These changes may help explain why the disease can damage so many different organs and why some people with long COVID have high levels of inflammation throughout the body. [Senators push IRS to launch nonprofit hospital probe](https://www.statnews.com/2023/08/08/senators-nonprofit-hospital-probe/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=269520932&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-_9YFSe1lHExs8MDgwVWnayT_R1Yz_xVTQaKGbX8zqSnxlblyRnHhBP1iS2Xj1tnNZJ6nqBeFyMJL5bZUA3FDwHHgdNUg&utm_content=269520932&utm_source=hs_email) August 8, 2023 A bipartisan group of senators wants federal tax regulators to probe nonprofit hospitals' compliance with community benefit requirements, ratcheting up a longtime campaign to hold the tax-exempt providers accountable. Nonprofit hospitals are often subsidized by state or federal funding and exempt from many taxes. In exchange, they are required to aid their surrounding area through public health programs and providing free or discounted care to low-income patients. However, advocates have long argued that the tax code's broad definition of community benefits has hospitals logging costs like physician training and research rather than direct community benefits like health screenings, free clinics, and care for the uninsured. Most of those vulnerable people live in 26 states and are expected to have at least five extreme heat days this month. Among the highest-risk counties, roughly 45% have high levels of uninsured adults and children and 18% have high senior populations, according to a relatively new monthly report drafted by the Health and Human Services Department's two-year-old climate change office. [Inside the hospital gardens that give respite from a world of ills](https://www.statnews.com/2023/07/24/hospital-gardens-patients/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=267555055&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-9c0UfTs5tQ5r4bOMKchhm5DXaOpSLwG11qocGKh6UjHeZsf-P3fXabfiMCxfrzuEzDTtkHBk65MM0CyH7oeOPuJcG3wg&utm_content=267555055&utm_source=hs_email) July 24, 2023 With the fall of King/Drew in 2007, and few health care facilities to serve the families of South LA for nearly a decade, county officials saw an opening. They bankrolled construction of a new, state-of-the-art MLK hospital in 2015, with a vow that this one would not fail its patients. This time, things would be different. In the stillness of the hospital's garden, one can lean into that trust. Right off the main lobby, between the ICU and a meditation room, is where the MLK "Azul Garden" lives. Azul as in blue, the color that permeates the breezeway through shade structures and lights and egg-shaped sculptures coated in pieces of blue glass. Blue as in the rectangle of sky overhead, the undertone of desert plants that line the walking path, as in healing. [Read more in this article](https://www.statnews.com/2023/07/24/hospital-gardens-patients/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=267555055&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-9c0UfTs5tQ5r4bOMKchhm5DXaOpSLwG11qocGKh6UjHeZsf-P3fXabfiMCxfrzuEzDTtkHBk65MM0CyH7oeOPuJcG3wg&utm_content=267555055&utm_source=hs_email) by Isabella Cueto in STAT Health. [Genetic cheat code might explain why some people catch Covid but never get sick](https://www.statnews.com/2023/07/19/why-people-catch-covid-but-never-get-sick/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=266993291&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-9MnNfbKb9iTR4E23jGzhhTNT8ppptRSlMWxBL2CXUjH4g9dwMytbW8v_D6UDB0bnMDo6C4k5cS4g3DcL3EtlE8Kv0AjQ&utm_content=266993291&utm_source=hs_email) July 19, 2023 What makes people able to clear SARS-CoV-2 out of their systems before it gains a foothold has been one of the enduring mysteries of the pandemic. Now, a group of scientists from the University of California, San Francisco, believes it has found an answer: It's in their genes. In a study published Wednesday in Nature, the team identified a mutation that increases a person's chance of being asymptomatic by nearly tenfold. "It's just one of these natural lucky breaks," said immunogeneticist Jill Hollenbach, who led the research. [Read more in this article](https://www.statnews.com/2023/07/19/why-people-catch-covid-but-never-get-sick/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=266993291&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-9MnNfbKb9iTR4E23jGzhhTNT8ppptRSlMWxBL2CXUjH4g9dwMytbW8v_D6UDB0bnMDo6C4k5cS4g3DcL3EtlE8Kv0AjQ&utm_content=266993291&utm_source=hs_email) by Megan Molteni in STAT In the Lab. [From rapid cooling body bags to 'prescriptions' for AC, doctors prepare for a future of extreme heat](https://www.statnews.com/2023/07/18/doctors-prepare-for-extreme-heat-climate-change/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=266839248&_hsenc=p2ANqtz--oyNQGKH56tAJVdbO-1N_fUYdfGuyP6YUu0O2-2Su4GO2mhdnPL9kqPptrjbM4GHQ5CPKdV9bdbZ9FSFOwYuK5MiPW5w&utm_content=266839248&utm_source=hs_email) July 18, 2023 In Phoenix, where daytime temperatures are topping 110 degrees Fahrenheit for the third straight week, emergency room doctors think of extreme heat as the public health emergency it has proved itself to be: In 2022, Arizona's Maricopa County reported a 25% increase in heat-related mortality from the previous year. "Heat is just something we know we need to be really worried about," said Geoff Comp, an emergency medicine physician at Valleywise Health Medical Center. Protocols developed by Comp, who is also associate program director of the Creighton School of Medicine/Valleywise emergency medicine residency, include treating heat stroke victims with the latest standard of care: immersive cooling in a body bag filled with ice and zipped to about shoulder level. [Read more in this article](https://www.statnews.com/2023/07/18/doctors-prepare-for-extreme-heat-climate-change/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=266839248&_hsenc=p2ANqtz--oyNQGKH56tAJVdbO-1N_fUYdfGuyP6YUu0O2-2Su4GO2mhdnPL9kqPptrjbM4GHQ5CPKdV9bdbZ9FSFOwYuK5MiPW5w&utm_content=266839248&utm_source=hs_email) by Karen Pennar in STAT Health. [One year into 988 hotline, staff push for fixes to ambitious new system](https://www.statnews.com/2023/07/12/988-mental-health-anniversary/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=266096414&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-8M4Cvlytpzirwa1bDbRT7WJV2iP6xZVWef9Xcjxy3aw3yF_JVtvWb4gzywV_bobzKjxl9kNkGKcnRKet6-Io0R-Emu2A&utm_content=266096414&utm_source=hs_email) July 12, 2023 In the year since the new, easy-to-remember 988 number went live, call center staff have worked hard to keep up with increasing calls to the system while also building new infrastructure to grow the program. There are over 200 local call centers across the country that answer the line, and nobody knew what to expect. Local leaders and directors at call centers say they're proud of how they've handled the last year, but that there's a lot of work left before the system works in the way everyone wants it to. A look at the particular issues plaguing 988 is a reminder of just how long the road is toward establishing a robust, reliable mental health crisis system. [Read more in this article](https://www.statnews.com/2023/07/12/988-mental-health-anniversary/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=266096414&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-8M4Cvlytpzirwa1bDbRT7WJV2iP6xZVWef9Xcjxy3aw3yF_JVtvWb4gzywV_bobzKjxl9kNkGKcnRKet6-Io0R-Emu2A&utm_content=266096414&utm_source=hs_email) by Theresa Gaffney in STAT Health Care. [As psychedelics near approval, there's no consensus on how they work](https://www.statnews.com/2023/07/03/psychedelics-ketamine-mdma-ptsd-how-they-work/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=264935548&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-8Sf5cfMuwEl2N-wbVLpr5_-9pGlUnWbM8c6L0pFR8FMAkQHwvC9tt5LTFmz_RKtlPrp7O5UsR-Ewt_FeHlFvIDHpaA2A&utm_content=264935548&utm_source=hs_email) July 3, 2023 Some of the earlier work on how psychedelics affect the brain was led by psychologist and neuroscientist Robin Carhart-Harris, who started his investigations at Imperial College London and is now a professor of neurology and psychiatry at the University of California, San Francisco. According to Carhart-Harris's research, which uses fMRI imaging to track brain activity, psilocybin disrupts the typically organized activity in the default mode network, an area of the brain associated with introspection, making existing thought patterns less dominant and creating the opportunity to develop new perspectives. [Read more in this article](https://www.statnews.com/2023/07/03/psychedelics-ketamine-mdma-ptsd-how-they-work/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=264935548&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-8Sf5cfMuwEl2N-wbVLpr5_-9pGlUnWbM8c6L0pFR8FMAkQHwvC9tt5LTFmz_RKtlPrp7O5UsR-Ewt_FeHlFvIDHpaA2A&utm_content=264935548&utm_source=hs_email) by Olivia Goldhill in STAT Health. [After affirmative action ruling, medical education leaders see silver lining in court endorsement of 'holistic review'](https://www.statnews.com/2023/06/30/affirmative-action-supreme-court-holistic-review/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=264690889&_hsenc=p2ANqtz--2bPYyj_E92kGiuBtNFOkVPxZphISMvWgFnk1JIjAbSjHzQ5tlbsSJZyoLfzrLXb0m9CQi1gIcVwQle9RXtToip4ZFuA&utm_content=264690889&utm_source=hs_email) June 30, 2023 After having a day to read through the Supreme Court's decision on affirmative action, some medical school and educational leaders are more hopeful that a path exists for them to diversify future classes and the health care workforce as they scramble to understand its impact on the next admissions cycle and the class of 2024. Several told STAT they saw the court's ruling as explicitly endorsing the use of "holistic review," a tool used increasingly by medical, dental, and nursing schools and other institutions to build classes that better reflect the demographics of the nation. For years, medical schools have been seeking to train physicians who better resemble the patients they treat — a key part of the effort to reduce health disparities. [Read more in this article](https://www.statnews.com/2023/06/30/affirmative-action-supreme-court-holistic-review/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=264690889&_hsenc=p2ANqtz--2bPYyj_E92kGiuBtNFOkVPxZphISMvWgFnk1JIjAbSjHzQ5tlbsSJZyoLfzrLXb0m9CQi1gIcVwQle9RXtToip4ZFuA&utm_content=264690889&utm_source=hs_email) by Usha Lee McFarling in STAT Politics. ['I felt like I was dying': How women with postpartum depression fall through the cracks of U.S. health care](https://www.statnews.com/2023/06/26/i-felt-like-i-was-dying-how-women-with-postpartum-depression-fall-through-the-cracks-of-u-s-health-care/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=264023155&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-80xdZz88U2pz_EbQ-qcL36lPy0sojbKZfT0rCsOQA0Wshs7YzMqJX9wixF_ZctsKsb65PHG5t2k45GseMv9SNLrecsQA&utm_content=264023155&utm_source=hs_email) June 26, 2023 Five and a half months after Kristina Dulaney had her second daughter, she developed postpartum psychosis. One day, she spontaneously quit her job as a nurse — which she doesn't remember doing. Soon after, she began to quote scripture, grabbed her kids, and begged God to save them all. Then she passed out, and her husband called 911. [Read more in this article](https://www.statnews.com/2023/06/26/i-felt-like-i-was-dying-how-women-with-postpartum-depression-fall-through-the-cracks-of-u-s-health-care/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=264023155&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-80xdZz88U2pz_EbQ-qcL36lPy0sojbKZfT0rCsOQA0Wshs7YzMqJX9wixF_ZctsKsb65PHG5t2k45GseMv9SNLrecsQA&utm_content=264023155&utm_source=hs_email) by Katharine Gammon in STAT Health. [Pregnancy-related death, like Tori Bowie's, is a far too common occurrence among Black women](https://www.statnews.com/2023/06/21/tori-bowie-black-maternal-death-racism/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=263440746&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-99VRDUUgQrN51z8b1UeHp2iuUgVoOqE91WLbyfaV0RzcxBj4FOqYZqC3ahbwIykzYy885z0FNhYRnJM8qb0zLkKdMzJA&utm_content=263440746&utm_source=hs_email) June 21, 2023 The horror stories of Black women dying or coming close to death in childbirth never seem to stop coming. The most recent headlines have been about the tragic case of three-time Olympian Tori Bowie, who died in her home from childbirth complications. Her teammate Tianna Madison wrote on Instagram, "THREE (3) of the FOUR (4) of us who ran on the SECOND fastest 4x100m relay of all time, the 2016 Olympic Champions have nearly died or died in childbirth." [Read more in this article](https://www.statnews.com/2023/06/21/tori-bowie-black-maternal-death-racism/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=263440746&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-99VRDUUgQrN51z8b1UeHp2iuUgVoOqE91WLbyfaV0RzcxBj4FOqYZqC3ahbwIykzYy885z0FNhYRnJM8qb0zLkKdMzJA&utm_content=263440746&utm_source=hs_email) by First Opinion. [Listen: 'Food apartheid' starves minority neighborhoods on Long Island](https://www.statnews.com/2023/06/19/food-apartheid-starves-minority-neighborhoods-on-long-island/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=263102136&_hsenc=p2ANqtz--Pm1Kv5uNUgdSrqRivGfUOmY5DHQL9-Jabo7_F4zIxULq-U7Zs5bWjx-8Ljfi4JmeALuROrwdPirHg-iJEt4ExgECDJQ&utm_content=263102136&utm_source=hs_email) June 19, 2023 James Boone wakes up at 6 a.m. nearly every Sunday, driving his van to Trader Joe's and other grocery stores on Long Island in order to rescue food destined for the dumpster. After gathering mountains of produce, Boone heads to a parking lot in his hometown of Hempstead, where a small army of volunteers joins him in unloading the bounty and packing the food into hundreds of cardboard boxes. [Medicaid adult dental benefits are shamefully — and dangerously — inadequate in most states](https://www.statnews.com/2023/06/14/medicaid-dental-benefits-adults-expansion/?utm_campaign=daily_recap&utm_medium=email&_hsmi=262513758&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-_gVtXHsGIF4NWcg1vKY-JXhbP7oHyuaKu1T8hKVyNUfUm35c5SCxXUYpfrHUL5F2f_o9rwdS624m-FLasuf1QC8aTnew&utm_content=262513758&utm_source=hs_email) June 14, 2023 In the middle of the night, you're jolted awake by a throbbing pain in your mouth that is radiating down your neck and behind your eyes. Earlier in the week, it was just a small toothache, but now over-the-counter remedies can't even begin to address the excruciating pain.
